quoteFirst: In some places the boys merely roll themselves up in blankets and sleep on the floor. The bootblacking stands are opened for business
quoteLast: , consequently the boys are obliged to rise about an hour earlier, and wherever their sleeping quarters are located at considerable distance from the stands, they have to get up as early as 4.30. Arrived at the stands, they remain working until 9.
title: Child Labor in City Streets
author: Clopper, Edward Nicholas, 1879-1953

title: Stories and Letters from the Trenches

quoteFirst: Price, of Walton, and after communicating with him my sister felt almost sure the prisoner was myself. Without a moment’s hesitation, and dressed just as she was, she caught the midnight train to Liverpool, where she arrived at
quoteLast: . She reached the doctor’s house at about seven and still was uncertain whether she would find me in the prison. Dr. Price, after some talk, took her to the Governor’s house.
title: Prisons & Prisoners: Some Personal Experiences
author: Lytton, Constance, Lady, 1869-1923

quoteFirst: Wright tells us, better than any one else, the story of the Hermit. She says: "This spring, the first week in May, when standing at the window
quoteTime: about six o'clock in the morning
quoteLast: , I heard an unusual note, and listened, thinking it at first a Wood Thrush and then a Thrasher, but soon finding that it was neither of these I opened the window softly and looked among the near by shrubs, with my glass. The wonderful melody ascended gradually in the scale as it progressed, now trilling, now legato, the most perfect, exalted, unrestrained, yet withal, finished bird song that I ever heard.
title:
Birds, Illustrated by Color Photography, Vol. 2, No. 3
September 1897
author: Various

quoteFirst: He desired to drink, but could not swallow, his pulse intermitted, his tongue swelled, his throat was excoriated, his breath difficult and interrupted. Towards morning he grew worse, became delirious and sank gradually, dying

quoteFirst: "Before daybreak I instructed the brigade commanders and the field-officer of the day to feel forward as far as possible, but all reported the enemy's pickets still in force in the dense woods to our front. But
quoteLast: a curious explosion, sounding like a volley of large siege-pieces, followed by others singly, and in twos and threes, arrested our attention, and soon after a large smoke arose from the direction of Corinth, when I telegraphed to General Halleck to ascertain the cause.
title:
Life of Wm. Tecumseh Sherman.
Late Retired General. U. S. A.

quoteFirst: _ The first feed and water is given as soon as the ducks are placed in the No. 1 brooder house or when 24 to 36 hours old. They are fed 3 times a day, in the morning
quoteLast: , at noon, and at night about 4:30 or 5 o'clock. The time of feeding should be regular, and fairly early in the morning but not any earlier in the afternoon than one can help so that the time between the evening and the morning feed will not be too long.
title: Ducks and Geese
author: Lamon, Harry M., 1872-; Slocum, Rob R. (Rob Roy), 1883-1944

quoteFirst: The commissioners were attended with a body of the National Guards, and all avenues of the section were watched to prevent any persons from escaping. They did not come to our hotel till
quoteLast: . I attended them through every room, and opened every door of our apartments. They behaved with great civility. We had no arms but pistols, which lay openly on the chimney.
title: The French Revolution of 1789, as Viewed in the Light of Republican Institutions

Capt.
title:
Privateering and Piracy in the Colonial Period

quoteFirst: The rich sheikh Emîn, of Gôs Burri, had given us his brother, the Fakîr Fadl Allah, as a guide, and his own son, Fadl Allah, as overseer of the camels; but even the nobles of the people here make a poor and evanescent impression in comparison with our conductors of Korusko. The order of the day here was this, that we generally set out
quoteTime: about six o’clock in the morning
quoteLast: , and continued going on until ten o’clock; then the caravan rested during the noonday heat till about three, when it journeyed again until ten or eleven o’clock at night.

quoteLast: ; he then gave himself a shake, bathed his face in an adjacent pool, and mounting a sand-hill, cast a glance over the country before him. Like William Thornton, he was at once attracted by the village spire, and the creek losing itself amongst the sand-hills.
